title: 1616-E
statement: E. Lexicographically Small Enoughtime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou are given two strings $$$s$$$ and $$$t$$$ of equal length $$$n$$$. In one move, you can swap any two adjacent characters of the string $$$s$$$.You need to find the minimal number of operations you need to make string $$$s$$$ lexicographically smaller than string $$$t$$$.A string $$$a$$$ is lexicographically smaller than a string $$$b$$$ if and only if one of the following holds:$$$a$$$ is a prefix of $$$b$$$, but $$$a \\ne b$$$;in the first position where $$$a$$$ and $$$b$$$ differ, the string $$$a$$$ has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in $$$b$$$.InputThe first line of input contains one integer $$$q$$$ ($$$1 \\le q \\le 10\\,000$$$): the number of test cases.The first line of each test case contains a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 10^5$$$).The second line of each test case contains the string $$$s$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ lowercase English letters.The third line of each test case contains the string $$$t$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ lowercase English letters.It is guaranteed that the sum of $$$n$$$ over all test cases does not exceed $$$2 \\cdot 10^5$$$.OutputFor each test case, print in a separate line the minimal number of operations you need to make string $$$s$$$ lexicographically smaller than string $$$t$$$, or $$$-1$$$, if it's impossible.ExampleInput4 1 a a 3 rll rrr 3 caa aca 5 ababa aabbaOutput-1 0 2 2

processed.result: You are given two strings of equal length $n$. You can swap any two adjacent characters in one of the strings.  Find the fewest swaps needed to make the first string smaller than the second string in alphabetical order. If it's impossible to make the first string smaller, output -1.

You have two equal-length strings of letters. You can swap any two adjacent letters in one string.  Find the fewest swaps needed to make the first string come before the second string in alphabetical order. If it's impossible, say -1.
